00074 /*
00075 * SHA-256/384/512 Machine Architecture Definitions 
00076 * BYTE_ORDER NOTE:
00077 *
00078 * Please make sure that your system defines BYTE_ORDER.  If your
00079 * architecture is little-endian, make sure it also defines
00080 * LITTLE_ENDIAN and that the two (BYTE_ORDER and LITTLE_ENDIAN) are
00081 * equivilent.
00082 *
00083 * If your system does not define the above, then you can do so by
00084 * hand like this:
00085 *
00086 *   #define LITTLE_ENDIAN 1234
00087 *   #define BIG_ENDIAN    4321
00088 *
00089 * And for little-endian machines, add:
00090 *
00091 *   #define BYTE_ORDER LITTLE_ENDIAN 
00092 *
00093 * Or for big-endian machines:
00094 *
00095 *   #define BYTE_ORDER BIG_ENDIAN
00096 *
00097 * The FreeBSD machine this was written on defines
00098 * BYTE_ORDER  appropriately by including <sys/types.h> 
00099 * (which in  turn includes <machine/endian.h> where the appropriate
00100 * definitions are actually made).
00101 */
00102 #define LITTLE_ENDIAN 1234
00103 #define BYTE_ORDER LITTLE_ENDIAN 
00104 #if !defined(BYTE_ORDER) || (BYTE_ORDER != LITTLE_ENDIAN && BYTE_ORDER != BIG_ENDIAN)
00105 #error Define BYTE_ORDER to be equal to either LITTLE_ENDIAN or BIG_ENDIAN
00106 #endif
00107 
00108 /*** ENDIAN REVERSAL MACROS *******************************************/
00109 #if BYTE_ORDER == LITTLE_ENDIAN
00110 #define REVERSE32(w,x)  { \
00111         sha2_word32 tmp = (w); \
00112         tmp = (tmp >> 16) | (tmp << 16); \
00113         (x) = ((tmp & 0xff00ff00UL) >> 8) | ((tmp & 0x00ff00ffUL) << 8); \
00114 }
00115 #define REVERSE64(w,x)  { \
00116         sha2_word64 tmp = (w); \
00117         tmp = (tmp >> 32) | (tmp << 32); \
00118         tmp = ((tmp & 0xff00ff00ff00ff00ULL) >> 8) | \
00119         ((tmp & 0x00ff00ff00ff00ffULL) << 8); \
00120         (x) = ((tmp & 0xffff0000ffff0000ULL) >> 16) | \
00121         ((tmp & 0x0000ffff0000ffffULL) << 16); \
00122 }
00123 #endif /* BYTE_ORDER == LITTLE_ENDIAN */
00124 
00125 /*
00126  * Macro for incrementally adding the unsigned 64-bit integer n to the
00127  * unsigned 128-bit integer (represented using a two-element array of
00128  * 64-bit words):
00129  */
00130 #define ADDINC128(w,n)  { \
00131         (w)[0] += (sha2_word64)(n); \
00132         if ((w)[0] < (n)) { \
00133                 (w)[1]++; \
00134         } \
00135 }
00136 
00137 /*
00138  * Macros for copying blocks of memory and for zeroing out ranges
00139  * of memory.  Using these macros makes it easy to switch from
00140  * using memset()/memcpy() and using bzero()/bcopy().
00141  *
00142  * Please define either SHA2_USE_MEMSET_MEMCPY or define
00143  * SHA2_USE_BZERO_BCOPY depending on which function set you
00144  * choose to use:
00145  */
00146 #if !defined(SHA2_USE_MEMSET_MEMCPY) && !defined(SHA2_USE_BZERO_BCOPY)
00147 /* Default to memset()/memcpy() if no option is specified */
00148 #define SHA2_USE_MEMSET_MEMCPY  1
00149 #endif
00150 #if defined(SHA2_USE_MEMSET_MEMCPY) && defined(SHA2_USE_BZERO_BCOPY)
00151 /* Abort with an error if BOTH options are defined */
00152 #error Define either SHA2_USE_MEMSET_MEMCPY or SHA2_USE_BZERO_BCOPY, not both!
00153 #endif
00154 
00155 #ifdef SHA2_USE_MEMSET_MEMCPY
00156 #define MEMSET_BZERO(p,l)       memset((p), 0, (l))
00157 #define MEMCPY_BCOPY(d,s,l)     memcpy((d), (s), (l))
00158 #endif
00159 #ifdef SHA2_USE_BZERO_BCOPY
00160 #define MEMSET_BZERO(p,l)       bzero((p), (l))
00161 #define MEMCPY_BCOPY(d,s,l)     bcopy((s), (d), (l))
00162 #endif
00163 
00164 /*** THE SIX LOGICAL FUNCTIONS ****************************************
00165  *
00166  * Bit shifting and rotation (used by the six SHA-XYZ logical functions:
00167  *
00168  *   NOTE:  The naming of R and S appears backwards here (R is a SHIFT and
00169  *   S is a ROTATION) because the SHA-256/384/512 description document
00170  *   (see http://csrc.nist.gov/cryptval/shs/sha256-384-512.pdf) uses this
00171  *   same "backwards" definition.
00172  */
00173 /* Shift-right (used in SHA-256, SHA-384, and SHA-512): */
00174 #define R(b,x)          ((x) >> (b))
00175 /* 32-bit Rotate-right (used in SHA-256): */
00176 #define S32(b,x)        (((x) >> (b)) | ((x) << (32 - (b))))
00177 /* 64-bit Rotate-right (used in SHA-384 and SHA-512): */
00178 #define S64(b,x)        (((x) >> (b)) | ((x) << (64 - (b))))
00179 
00180 /* Two of six logical functions used in SHA-256, SHA-384, and SHA-512: */
00181 #define Ch(x,y,z)       (((x) & (y)) ^ ((~(x)) & (z)))
00182 #define Maj(x,y,z)      (((x) & (y)) ^ ((x) & (z)) ^ ((y) & (z)))
00183 
00184 /* Four of six logical functions used in SHA-256: */
00185 #define Sigma0_256(x)   (S32(2,  (x)) ^ S32(13, (x)) ^ S32(22, (x)))
00186 #define Sigma1_256(x)   (S32(6,  (x)) ^ S32(11, (x)) ^ S32(25, (x)))
00187 #define sigma0_256(x)   (S32(7,  (x)) ^ S32(18, (x)) ^ R(3 ,   (x)))
00188 #define sigma1_256(x)   (S32(17, (x)) ^ S32(19, (x)) ^ R(10,   (x)))
00189 
00190 /* Four of six logical functions used in SHA-384 and SHA-512: */
00191 #define Sigma0_512(x)   (S64(28, (x)) ^ S64(34, (x)) ^ S64(39, (x)))
00192 #define Sigma1_512(x)   (S64(14, (x)) ^ S64(18, (x)) ^ S64(41, (x)))
00193 #define sigma0_512(x)   (S64( 1, (x)) ^ S64( 8, (x)) ^ R( 7,   (x)))
00194 #define sigma1_512(x)   (S64(19, (x)) ^ S64(61, (x)) ^ R( 6,   (x)))
